author: By Matt Yan
title: A Filipino Holiday Tradition, Perhaps Best Not Made at Home
description: This year, I found a new way to celebrate my heritage through parols, colorful star-shaped lanterns.
content: When I was a kid, Christmas at our house always looked like a Hallmark movie, as if my Filipino immigrant family was trying its best to fit in with mainstream American culture. Think stockings, classic holiday tunes (our favorite is “Last Christmas”) and ornaments.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quote of the Day: New Starring Role for a Lamb Of ’90s TV: Dog’s Best Friend
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, December 7, 2024
content: “Yes, I am a cult leader. I control the dogs.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paula Span
title: Payments Are Going Digital, but Many Seniors Still Rely on Cash
description: “We’re putting another burden on the elderly that we don’t have to,” one researcher said.
content: Some things you can no longer do with cash: Buy a well-loaded hot dog at any of the five Devil Dawgs eateries in and around Chicago. Order a Vermont Pale Lager from Hill Farmstead Brewery’s taproom in Greensboro Bend, Vt.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: A.I. Will Transform the Global Economy — if Humans Let It
description: We asked a group of business leaders to consider how businesses can benefit from artificial intelligence.
content: This feature is part of a series called Turning Points, in which writers explore what critical moments from this year might mean for the year ahead. You can read more by visiting the Turning Points series page.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyson Krueger
title: It’s Our Wedding, and You’ll Run if We Want To
description: Some couples choose to kick off their big day with a group 5K. Sometimes guests join them.
content: During their wedding weekend in September in Nantucket, Mass., Larry Giannechini, 34, and Pat Knise, 35, held many traditional activities. They staged a welcome dinner. Their wedding was at a private club with a ceremony and a reception. Brunch was the next day.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Short, Sweet Reads for Fans of the American Absurd
description: A Don DeLillo novel; a Joy Williams short story.
content: Dear readers,
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ségolène Le Stradic
title: Trump and Prince William Headline Guest List at Notre-Dame Reopening
description: Dozens of officials have been invited to Paris as the rebuilt cathedral welcomes visitors five years after a devastating fire.
content: Dozens of foreign officials have been invited to Paris for the reopening of Notre-Dame Cathedral five years after it was nearly destroyed in a fire.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Notre-Dame Reopens: Photos
description: As Notre-Dame reopens after a 2019 fire, here is a selection of scenes from the famous Paris cathedral during a weekend of preparations and ceremonies.
content: Heads of state, religious leaders and other dignitaries attended the ceremonies on Saturday that marked the reopening of Notre-Dame Cathedral.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: Teens Are Getting Botox. I’m Going Full Crone in 2025.
description: In pushing back against beauty standards, I’m trying to set an example for my girls.
content: Whenever I can, I try to deprogram my daughters from the overwhelming cultural imperative to look conventionally hot forever. Sometimes this involves showing my eldest daughter videos of women older than me who I admire. This is my way of pushing back against the idea that we should do everything in our power to look younger.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: Zelensky Met With Trump in Paris to Press Ukraine’s Case
description: The Ukrainian leader planned to use the grand reopening of Notre-Dame Cathedral to lobby the president-elect and other world leaders attending the ceremony.
content: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine met with President-elect Donald J. Trump in Paris on Saturday, the first face-to-face encounter between the two since Mr. Trump won the U.S. presidential election last month after claiming that he would end the war in 24 hours.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger, Jonathan Swan and Maggie Haberman
title: Want a Job in the Trump Administration? Be Prepared for the Loyalty Test.
description: Applicants for government posts, including inside the Pentagon and the intelligence agencies, say they have been asked about their thoughts on Jan. 6 and who they believe won the 2020 election.
content: At the Trump transition offices in West Palm Beach, Fla., prospective occupants of high posts inside the Pentagon and the intelligence agencies typically run through a gamut of three to four interviews, conducted in recent weeks by a mix of Silicon Valley investors and innovators and a team of the MAGA faithful.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Small and Shiho Fukada
title: TeamLab, Art’s Greatest Sugar Rush, Is Building an Empire
description: The art collective behind teamLab, which started in Japan, has expanded across the world, developing partnerships to pay for its immersive technology.
content: During an economically challenging period for many cultural institutions, a collective of artists and engineers have lured millions of visitors into their global network of nearly 60 perfectly Instagrammable, immersive art centers and exhibitions, expanding from Japan to China and Saudi Arabia, and, soon, to the United Arab Emirates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Doleac
title: What Republicans and Democrats Get Wrong About Crime
description: An evidence-based approach to criminal justice would tell us that policing works and long prison sentences do not.
content: Americans are understandably concerned about crime. Before the 2024 election, voters consistently ranked it among their top priorities. At least two states rolled back reforms this year, and prison populations in many states are starting to rise again after nearly a decade of declines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Theodore Schleifer, Maggie Haberman and Jonathan Swan
title: The Silicon Valley Billionaires Steering Trump’s Transition
description: The involvement of wealthy investors has made this presidential transition one of the most potentially conflict-ridden in modern history.
content: The week after the November election, President-elect Donald J. Trump gathered his top advisers in the tearoom at his Florida resort, Mar-a-Lago, to plan the transition to his second-term government.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Williams
title: Silvia Pinal, Golden Age Star of Mexican Cinema, Is Dead
description: She found outsize success in her native land and gained international recognition for her work with the acclaimed Spanish surrealist director Luis Buñuel.
content: Silvia Pinal, an award-winning actress who was considered one of the great stars of Mexico’s golden age of cinema, and who earned worldwide acclaim for her work with the groundbreaking Spanish-born Surrealist director Luis Buñuel, died on Nov. 28 in Mexico City.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Fahy
title: Special Education Services With a Catch: Parents Are Asked Not to Sue
description: New York City school officials want families seeking such services to waive their right to sue the Education Department in exchange for receiving them.
content: New York City parents who missed a rarely enforced deadline to apply for their children’s special education services can now receive those services, but only if they agree not to sue the Education Department.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas and Rory Doyle
title: A Mississippi Teacher Created a School in an Empty Storefront. Students Showed Up.
description: The desks came out of a dumpster, and the computers are hand-me-downs. But students say Abundance Academy is a haven from bullying and crowded classes.
content: Leora Hooper, as usual, had a busy school day ahead of her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: Year in Review
description: As critics issue their year-end lists, we want to know your personal favorites of 2024.
content: It’s the most wonderful time of year, and I don’t mean the holiday season, although I’ve heard that people are excited about that too. No, for nerds like me who love to plan out their holiday culture consumption — those whose appetites are always far larger than their capacity for viewing/reading/listening — December is sacred because it is when critics issue their retrospective best-of lists, their verdicts on the best movies, music, TV, books and other cultural artifacts of 2024.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Dec. 7, 2024
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Dec. 7, 2024.
content: An article on Wednesday about Sheriff Chad Chronister, President-elect Donald J. Trump’s pick to lead the Drug Enforcement Administration, withdrawing his name from consideration for the office misstated Pam Bondi’s role at the Hillsborough County State Attorney’s Office. She was a prosecutor in and a spokeswoman for the office; she was not in charge of it.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Is the Real ‘Wicked’ Movie the Press Tour?
description: A conversation about the musical’s transfer from stage to screen, and the lead actresses who are bringing new narratives to their roles.
content: The film adaptation of the Broadway musical “Wicked” has been long in the works and perhaps anticipated for even longer. Starring Ariana Grande (billed as Ariana Grande-Butera) as Galinda and Cynthia Erivo as Elphaba, it is an ornate adventure that serves as a sort of prequel to “The Wizard of Oz.” (It is also the first of two films; the second one will be released next November.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Haag and Patrick McGeehan
title: An N.Y.P.D. Manhunt Caught a Subway Shooter. This Time, It’s Different.
description: Capturing a suspect who slips away from a crime scene requires solid police work, help from the public and a little luck, experts say. So far, it’s not working.
content: A shocking early morning act of violence, a frantic New York Police Department search for a suspect and a gunman seemingly in the wind: The year was 2022, and the man the police had fanned out to find was Frank R. James, who had set off smoke grenades inside a crowded subway car in Brooklyn and opened fire.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: Which Colleges Offer Free Tuition?
description: Dozens of schools say they provide free tuition to students whose families earn under a certain income. How does it work?
content: In the last month, several colleges and universities, including the University of Texas system and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, have announced programs to provide free tuition for undergraduate students from families who fall below a certain income threshold.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Thomas and Jessica Silver-Greenberg
title: Fraud and Fakery at the Country’s Largest Chain of Methadone Clinics
description: Acadia Healthcare falsifies records at its methadone clinics and enrolls patients who aren’t addicted to opioids, a Times investigation found.
content: Every day at dawn, tens of thousands of people begin lining up at Acadia Healthcare’s addiction clinics to get a cup of methadone. The daily dose staves off opioid withdrawal and keeps many from turning to dangerous street drugs like fentanyl.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jess Bidgood and Shane Goldmacher
title: Fighting Over a ‘Flawless’ Campaign
description: Leaders of the Trump and Harris campaigns met this week to talk tactics. It wasn’t pretty.
content: Reader, we wrote you this newsletter in a tense room in Cambridge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Leigh-Ann Jackson
title: Luke Wilson Finds Inspiration in Michael Heizer’s Desert ‘City’
description: “Probably the coolest thing I’ve seen in person,” said the actor, one of the stars of the Netflix TV series “No Good Deed.”
content: The concept of a self-reliant solitary figure “working hard toward a singular goal” appeals to the actor Luke Wilson.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vjosa Isai
title: Canada’s 988 Crisis Hotline, a ‘Pathway to Survival,’ One Year Later
description: The hotline responded to more than 300,000 calls and texts in its inaugural year, reinforcing appeals for Canada to establish a national suicide prevention strategy.
content: In his hit song about his mental health struggles, the American rapper Logic did something unusual. Instead of giving the song a name, he assigned it a number, that of the 11-digit National Suicide Prevention Lifeline.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lydia DePillis
title: The Climate Risk to the Mortgage System
description: Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, which backstop most U.S. mortgages, know floods and fires are a growing problem. But little action has been taken.
content: As sea levels rise and natural disasters become more intense, homes in low-lying coastal areas or tinder-dry mountains are starting to lose value.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: The Police Offer a Detailed Timeline of the Gunman’s Movements
description: Investigators have begun to piece together the actions of a man they believe killed a health care executive on a city sidewalk early Wednesday morning.
content: The police on Friday offered a nearly minute-by-minute timeline of a gunman’s movements before and after he fatally shot Brian Thompson, the chief executive of UnitedHealthcare, in Midtown Manhattan two days earlier.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Marchese
title: Tilda Swinton Would Like a Word With Trump About His Mother
description: The Academy Award-winning actress discusses her lifelong quest for connection, humanity’s innate goodness and the point of being alive.
content: Unexpected, even uncanny, connections sometimes arise in this job. An interviewee might, for example, raise an idea that chimes with something I’ve long been thinking about. Or I’ll find while doing research that someone’s work illuminates a problem I’d been dealing with. Two such surprises occurred with this week’s subject, the Academy Award-winning actress Tilda Swinton. Both shaped my feeling about the ensuing conversation, though in very different ways.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced and Lauren Hirsch
title: Why Jeff Bezos Likes ‘Messy’ Meetings
description: The billionaire founder of Amazon spoke with Andrew Ross Sorkin at the DealBook Summit.
content: Jeff Bezos, the billionaire founder of Amazon and the owner of The Washington Post, defended his decision to end presidential endorsements at The Post and expressed optimism about a second Trump administration at the DealBook Summit on Wednesday. But he also delved into his personal philosophy in his discussion with Andrew, including how he approaches entrepreneurship and leadership.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: How to Understand Syria’s Rapidly Changing Civil War
description: Advances by a coalition of opposition groups have abruptly changed the landscape of Syria’s civil war after a long stalemate. Here’s a closer look at where things stand.
content: Rebel groups fighting to depose President Bashar al-Assad of Syria battled regime forces on the outskirts of the strategic city of Homs on Saturday as they pushed toward the capital, Damascus, according to the rebels and a war monitoring group.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion No. 546
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Sunday, Dec. 8, 2024.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Talya Minsberg
title: You Don’t Have to Be Injured to Benefit from Physical Therapy
description: A good P.T. can help you improve your strength and mobility. Here’s how to find the right fit.
content: I cried when I graduated college — because I had to say goodbye to my physical therapist. He had brought me back from many running injuries and patiently talked me down when I wanted to start training again before I was ready.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Shirky
title: The Fragility of Bluesky’s Difference
description: Users are looking for a more curated experience on a platform that is not constantly trying to get them to interact with brands.
content: Liberals moving away from X are giving up on the 20th-century ideal of a public sphere, best described by Hannah Arendt as a place that “gathers us together and yet prevents our falling over each other.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles
title: 1984: The Year Pop Stardom Got Supersized
description: In a peak moment of pop monoculture, synthesizers pumped up songs and MTV forever changed how artists were seen. Here’s how — and why.
content: Forty years ago, the chemistry of pop stardom was irrevocably changed. Nineteen eighty-four was an inflection point: a year of blockbuster albums, career quantum leaps, iconic poses and an enduring redefinition of what pop success could mean for performers — and would then demand from them — in the decades to come.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Yoon and Brolley Genster
title: Disappointed Protesters Vow to Keep Pressure on South Korea’s Yoon
description: Demonstrations in the city and nationwide demanding the president’s ouster intensified through the week, and Saturday’s rally was the largest yet.
content: Tens of thousands of protesters massed outside South Korea’s National Assembly on Saturday, calling for President Yoon Suk Yeol’s ouster as the lawmakers inside voted on whether to impeach him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: JD Vance, Elon Musk and the Future of America
description: How the two men’s visions for America come together, or clash, is a key to the new administration’s success.
content: Beneath all the furor around Donald Trump’s appointments — Matt Gaetz down and out, Pete Hegseth down but maybe coming back, the Kash Patel drama waiting in the wings — the most important figures in this administration’s orbit have not changed since Election Day: Besides the president himself, the future of Trumpism is still most likely to be shaped and stamped by two men, JD Vance and Elon Musk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simon J. Levien
title: Trump Attends Notre-Dame Ceremony in First Foreign Trip Since Election
description: At the ceremony, the president-elect took a seat next to President Emmanuel Macron of France, with whom he has had a rocky relationship.
content: President-elect Donald J. Trump made a splashy re-entry onto the global stage on Saturday as he attended the reopening ceremony of the Notre-Dame Cathedral, sitting in the front row between President Emmanuel Macron of France and the French first lady, Brigitte Macron.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Entous
title: U.S. Spy Agencies Monitor Chemical Weapons Storage Sites, Fearing Use in Syria
description: But aides to President Biden have made clear that the United States has no intention of intervening in support of either President Bashar al-Assad or the rebels.
content: U.S. intelligence agencies are closely monitoring suspected chemical weapons storage sites in Syria, looking for indications that forces loyal to President Bashar al-Assad are preparing to employ them against the collection of rebel groups fighting to depose him, officials said Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hank Sanders
title: 2 Indianapolis Officers Are Acquitted of Manslaughter in 2022 Death
description: Herman Whitfield III had told officers “I’m dying” and that he couldn’t breathe after one of the officers deployed a Taser, according to body camera footage.
content: Two Indianapolis police officers were acquitted on Friday of involuntary manslaughter charges in the 2022 death of Herman Whitfield III, after he was handcuffed and placed face down by the officers, who were responding to reports that he was having a mental health crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niki Kitsantonis
title: Athens’s New Answer to a Water Supply Crunch: An Ancient Aqueduct
description: Hadrian’s Aqueduct supplied water to Greece’s capital for centuries but was then largely abandoned. It’s being revived to ease water scarcity amid global warming.
content: After climate change brought another year of record-breaking heat and dwindling rainfall to Greece, the reservoirs that supply water to Athens have dropped to their lowest levels in over a decade. Farmers are struggling to produce crops, wildfires have increased the demand for water and priests are conducting prayers for rain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins and Matei Barbulescu
title: In a Romanian Village, Anger Fuels Support for an Ultranationalist ‘Messiah’
description: A presidential election has been called off, but the discontent that propelled the surging campaign of a rightist firebrand rages on.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Nolen and Moses Sawasawa
title: Sex, a Hex and a Sick Child Offer Clues to an Epidemic’s Birth
description: In a remote Congolese town, a medical mystery led to the discovery of alarming changes in the mpox virus and, eventually, to a global health emergency.
content: On Sept. 30, 2023, an anxious father brought his 5-year-old son to the hospital in Kamituga, a muddy, bustling town carved out of the thick forest in the eastern Democratic Republic of Congo. The boy had a high fever and oozing sores on his torso and face.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Kim
title: South Korea’s Leader Survives Impeachment Vote After His Power Grab
description: The country was thrown into deeper uncertainty after the governing party changed its stance and refused to oust him. Protesters vowed to keep the pressure on.
content: South Korean lawmakers’ attempt to impeach President Yoon Suk Yeol ended in failure on Saturday night, prolonging the political upheaval and uncertainty that has roiled the country since his short-lived imposition of martial law this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Calum Marsh
title: Indiana Jones Chooses Wisely: The Biggest Voice in Gaming
description: Troy Baker, the industry’s go-to voice actor, channels a young Harrison Ford in the action-adventure Indiana Jones and the Great Circle.
content: When Todd Howard heard the name Troy Baker, he could not help but roll his eyes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raja Abdulrahim
title: Syria’s Government Battles Multiple Rebel Uprisings
description: The longtime Syrian dictator Bashar al-Assad is facing threats from rebellions on numerous fronts as his key ally, Iran, is paring back support.
content: President Bashar al-Assad’s political survival was under threat on Saturday as the Syrian government battled opposition rebellions around the country and the strategic city of Homs was breached by the main rebel coalition, according to the fighters and a war monitor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabino Iglesias
title: The Best Horror Fiction of 2024
description: We’re in a golden age of horror. Here are 10 books that stood out in a year filled with fantastic releases.
content: Readers, good news: We’re in a golden age of horror. The year 2024 was packed with amazing — and amazingly diverse — horror novels, novellas and collections. It brought highly anticipated returns of horror legends and bold introductions of new voices to the genre; featured a range of topics, from cosmic horror to haunted houses; and explored a variety of cultures, with deep dives into Latin America, spotlights on Korean Americans and more.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Callie Holtermann and Sapna Maheshwari
title: ‘It’s for Real This Time’: TikTok Creators React to Potential Ban
description: The social media service was flooded with videos on Friday after a panel of judges upheld a law that could shutter the app in the United States.
content: TikTok creators took to the app to express their shock and dismay on Friday after a panel of federal judges unanimously upheld a new law that could lead to the popular Chinese-owned video app being banned in the United States by mid-January.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Warrell
title: Lust and Loss in the Upper Ranks of the Black Panther Party
description: Fabienne Josaphat’s novel “Kingdom of No Tomorrow” sets a love triangle amid late-1960s Oakland and Chicago.
content: In her muscular, searing novel “Kingdom of No Tomorrow,” the poet and fiction writer Fabienne Josaphat fixes her lens on the late 1960s, a time of turmoil and transformation for Black people the world over. Her protagonist, Nettie Boileau, emerges from the Haiti of Josaphat’s debut, “Dancing in the Baron’s Shadow” — where the brutal Duvalier dictatorship murdered as many as 60,000 people — into 1968 Oakland, Calif., and Chicago, where the Black Panther Party is fighting for Black liberation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farnaz Fassihi
title: In the Syrian Regime’s Hour of Need, Its Patron Iran Makes an Exit
description: The collapse of a partnership built over four decades would reshape the balance of power in the Middle East.
content: For decades, Iran has expended much blood and money in support of Syria’s president, Bashar al-Assad, helping him survive a civil war that threatened his dynastic rule. Iran operated military bases, weapons warehouses and missile factories in Syria, which it used as a pipeline for arming its militant allies across the region.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farnaz Fassihi and Ronen Bergman
title: Iran Begins to Evacuate Military Officials and Personnel From Syria
description: The withdrawals by one of President Bashar al-Assad’s key backers come amid a resurgent rebel offensive.
content: Iran began to evacuate its military commanders and personnel from Syria on Friday, according to regional officials and three Iranian officials, in a sign of Iran’s inability to help keep President Bashar al-Assad in power as he faces a resurgent rebel offensive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Hanlon
title: Why Are We So Obsessed With the Moon?
description: Lunar exploration in the 21st century offers a unique opportunity to unite us.
content: This personal reflection is part of a series called Turning Points, in which writers explore what critical moments from this year might mean for the year ahead. You can read more by visiting the Turning Points series page.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ray Fisman
title: Why Running the Government Like a Business Would Be a Disaster
description: A lot of what the government does is hard to quantify and involves complicated tasks that inevitably require bureaucratic coordination and, yes, inefficiency.
content: The fact that President-elect Donald Trump has tapped two businessmen — Elon Musk and Vivek Ramaswamy — to lead an advisory commission focused on streamlining government operations suggests that these efficiencies will come from making the government run more like a business. In 2017, when he was a White House adviser, Jared Kushner, who now runs a private equity firm, made a similar pitch that business thinking would help to “achieve successes and efficiencies for our customers, who are the citizens.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi, busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. Enter the comments section to see hints, conversation, helpful tips and creative content from other solvers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum and Alice Callahan
title: Is Milk Safe? Your Questions About Bird Flu and Dairy, Answered.
description: Federal officials will soon begin testing the country’s milk supply for the virus. Here’s what to know.
content: The U.S. Department of Agriculture announced Friday that it would soon begin testing the country’s milk supply for H5N1, the virus that causes avian influenza.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Conor Dougherty
title: How Easy Rawlins Built a Real Estate Empire, One Crime Novel at a Time
description: Walter Mosley talks about how his fictional hero frees himself from wage labor through America’s favorite side hustle: landlording.
content: About a third of the way through “Farewell, Amethystine,” the latest novel in the author Walter Mosley’s series about a private investigator named Ezekiel (Easy) Rawlins, Easy sets out for a late-night meeting with a gun and a hunch.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Just for Fun
description: John Kugelman’s puzzle turns on solvers, with a switch of the flip.
content: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil MacFarquhar
title: In Fight for Syria, a Battle for Domination of the Entire Middle East
description: In a region “already on fire,” analysts say, rebels’ advance toward Damascus is a barometer of the shifting power dynamics that also affect nations like Iran, Turkey, Russia and the United States.
content: As armed rebels have advanced at lightning speed in recent days from the north of Syria toward the capital, Damascus, footage online showed statues of the Assad dynasty — which has kept the country in its authoritarian grip for over 50 years — crashing to the ground.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Orli’s Gift, in Her Life and Death
description: Readers respond to Sarah Wildman’s essay about her daughter’s lessons in facing mortality.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset, Catherine Porter and Thomas Fuller
title: With Pageantry and Dignitaries, France Unveils a Reborn Notre-Dame
description: Five years after a ruinous fire, the reopening of the cathedral restored it in full glory to the Paris skyline and delivered a much-needed morale boost for France.
content: Five years after a fire that devoured its roof and nearly collapsed its walls, a renovated Notre-Dame Cathedral reopened its doors on Saturday, its centuries-old bell clanging, its 8,000-pipe organ first groaning — and then roaring back to life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Mogg and Catherine Pearson
title: Why Friendship Breakups Hurt So Much
description: And how to lessen the blow.
content: When Krystle Dullas’s close friend left their city for an extended cross-country road trip in 2022, they vowed to stay in touch. But as life got busier, their long telephone conversations and video exchanges slowly dissipated, Ms. Dullas said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andy Newman and Maria Cramer
title: Detectives Scour Thousands of Hours of Video for Clues in C.E.O. Killing
description: Cameras are everywhere in Manhattan and they helped lead investigators to a distinctive backpack in Central Park that could be a key piece of physical evidence.
content: It was footage from surveillance cameras that told the police that the man they suspect of murdering an insurance executive on Wednesday had arrived in New York City on a bus more than a week before.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson and Alexis Soloski
title: What I Learned at Shiz University: How ‘Wicked’ Changed the Lives of Its Stars
description: Only the women who’ve played Elphaba and Glinda in the show’s two decades onstage understand why the roles are so taxing — and so rewarding, too.
content: The graduates of Shiz University are making their alma mater proud.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kwame Anthony Appiah
title: A Guy I Know Had a Liver Transplant. Now He’s Boozing Again.
description: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on how to support someone with an addiction problem.
content: My significant other has a friend who is a longtime alcoholic, while also being intelligent, entertaining and conniving. For example, he used to tell his wife he was going to the gym and then head to the bar; before returning home, he’d dampen his clothes in the bathroom to make it seem as if he’d gotten a good sweat on. He was off the radar for a bit, and then we learned he had a liver transplant. After that, he had an episode of hepatic encephalopathy, a brain disorder caused by liver dysfunction. It seems the doctors knew he was still drinking but gave him the new liver anyway and counseled abstinence. A few parties later, he was sneaking vodka, gin and whatever else was around. He lies to everyone and has made his guy friends vow not to tell his wife about his drinking. They’ve made a meager attempt to confront him, only to be assured that he just fell off the wagon and would be good. Just don’t tell the wife!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aurelien Breeden and Ségolène Le Stradic
title: Notre-Dame Reopening: Schedule of Events and How to Watch
description: A speech by President Emmanuel Macron and a religious service will precede the broadcast of a taped concert by French and international musical artists.
content: Ceremonies for the reopening of Notre-Dame on Saturday — five years after a fire badly damaged the medieval cathedral in the heart of Paris — are scheduled to begin at 7 p.m. (1 p.m. Eastern). A live video stream is here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Nehamas, Maya King and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: How Alarmed Harris Staffers Went Rogue to Reach Black and Latino Voters
description: Worried that the campaign was neglecting voters of color in Philadelphia and other battleground cities, organizers secretly gathered at a Dunkin’ Donuts and elsewhere to get out the vote.
content: Two days before the November election, a rogue team of campaign organizers for Vice President Kamala Harris turned a Dunkin’ Donuts in Philadelphia into their secret headquarters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacob Bernstein
title: To Show His Health Credentials, Kennedy Ditches His Shirt
description: Robert F. Kennedy Jr., President-elect Trump’s choice to lead the Department of Health and Human Services, has repeatedly showed off his physique on social media.
content: Well before he gave up on his campaign for the presidency and threw his support to Donald J. Trump, Robert F. Kennedy Jr. was posting thirst traps of himself on social media.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nabil Ayers
title: A Wrong Turn in Mississippi
description: The winding road of tracking down a family tree.
content: Holly Springs, Miss., a city of 7,000 residents, lies 56 miles southeast of Memphis. It was once a lively center of the cotton trade, and as I recently learned from a newfound cousin, it is also where my enslaved ancestors lived.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mia Leimkuhler
title: Salty, Sweet, Spicy, Smoky Mie Goreng
description: These versatile Indonesian stir-fried noodles strike a perfect balance of flavors that you’ll want to eat again and again (speaking from experience).
content: Something I’ve learned adapting recipes for New York Times Cooking is that, in the process of fine-tuning chefs’ recipes for home cooks, you have to make the recipe a lot, eating the dish on repeat for several days straight. I had the great pleasure of making this mie goreng with the chef Zulfikar Fahd, the owner of Java Bali Kitchen in Toronto, a couple of times in my own home. After he left, I made it a few more times to get the details right.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hurubie Meko
title: Some on Social Media See Suspect in C.E.O. Killing as a Folk Hero
description: The authorities have pleaded for help in finding the person who killed Brian Thompson, the chief executive of UnitedHealthcare. But some seem more interested in rooting for the gunman.
content: A grainy image of his face drew comparisons to Hollywood heartthrobs. A jacket similar to the one he’s wearing on wanted posters is reportedly flying off the shelves. And the words written on the bullets he used to kill a man in cold blood on a sidewalk on Wednesday have become, for some people, a rallying cry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: South Korean Leader’s Deal to Avoid Impeachment Risks Bigger Turmoil
description: President Yoon Suk Yeol survived an opposition-led attempt to remove him by getting his party members to back him. But his troubles could now become theirs too.
content: The failure by South Korea’s opposition parties on Saturday to impeach President Yoon Suk Yeol for issuing his country’s first declaration of martial law in more than four decades set the stage for prolonged political uncertainty and turmoil in one of Washington’s most important allies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David J. Morris
title: The Disappearance of Literary Men Should Worry Everyone
description: What happens if half the population is no longer involved in reading and writing?
content: Over the past two decades, literary fiction has become a largely female pursuit. Novels are increasingly written by women and read by women. In 2004, about half the authors on the New York Times fiction best-seller list were women and about half men; this year, the list looks to be more than three-quarters women. According to multiple reports, women readers now account for about 80 percent of fiction sales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: What’s on Your Best-of List for 2024? We Want to Know.
description: Best cocktail or mocktail? Best advice? Best app you discovered? We want to know your highly subjective, hyper-specific, genre-agnostic favorites from the past year.
content: What’s on your best-of list for 2024? Forget about genre, forget the usual year-end list categories and think about everything you consumed. What was the best breakfast you devised? The best song lyric? The best tradition you started or ended, the best movie you rediscovered, the best piece of advice you received? Make up your own categories! Go wild! (For inspiration, check out reader favorites from past years.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Terreri Ramos
title: I Want to Renovate My Rental. How Much Trouble Can I Get Into?
description: Tenants typically cannot make alterations or improvements to an apartment without permission. Unauthorized upgrades could lead to eviction.
content: Q: We’ve been fortunate to live in a rent-stabilized apartment on the Upper East Side for more than 40 years. Although it’s a rental, we have treated it as our own, making cosmetic changes along the way. Our kitchen is nearly 60 years old and needs new cabinets and countertops, and several rooms need to be painted. The building’s painter would paint the rooms we want, but would not move any of our things and would not repair large chips in the kitchen cabinets. The landlord has renovated vacant apartments, but the quality is poor. We’d like to make these changes on our own, at our expense, but our landlord says no. What can we do?
source.name: The New York Times

title: President Yoon’s Speech Apologizing for Martial Law
description: President Yoon Suk Yeol said his declaration of martial law was born out of “desperation,” and apologized for causing “anxiety.”
content: President Yoon Suk Yeol of South Korea delivered the following televised address on Saturday morning:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Wordle Review No. 1,268
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Sunday, Dec. 8, 2024.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitch Smith
title: Akron Police Face Questions After Officer Fatally Shoots Teenager
description: The Ohio city’s mayor and the family of the 15-year-old, Jazmir Tucker, raised concerns about how officers handled the incident.
content: Newly released video of the fatal November police shooting of Jazmir Tucker, a 15-year-old high school student in Akron, Ohio, has led to pointed questions from the city’s mayor and the teenager’s family about how officers handled the incident.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simon J. Levien
title: Trump Heads to Notre-Dame Ceremony in First Foreign Trip Since Election
description: The president-elect will be at the cathedral alongside dozens of world leaders. He was also meeting with President Emmanuel Macron of France, with whom he has had a rocky relationship.
content: President-elect Donald J. Trump was meeting on Saturday with President Emmanuel Macron of France before attending the reopening ceremony of the Notre-Dame Cathedral, making a splashy re-entry onto the global stage in his first foreign trip since winning the presidential election in November.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Goldberg
title: What if Charity Shouldn’t Be Optimized?
description: The recent trend in philanthropy has been to look for the most bang for your buck. Maybe you don’t have to.
content: Equipped with tools to measure our calories, steps, working hours, wasted hours, water intake and sleep cycles, we have now been exhorted to measure our charitable impact, too. Books, podcasts, TikToks and digital guides implore us to donate our money cautiously, rationally, to the charities that promise to make a dollar go the furthest it can. Holiday season giving can start to feel a little like sports betting: It doesn’t matter if you’re loyal to a scrappy local team — the data can tell you exactly where your money should go.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Siege Deterrents
description: Luke K. Schreiber makes a stone-cold Saturday puzzle debut.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This pinwheel grid is Luke K. Schreiber’s first themeless construction for The New York Times after a Monday, a Wednesday and a memorably witty Sunday puzzle whose theme used visual puns. The arrangement of entries here, in big, open blocks, is not unusual for a Friday or a Saturday, but I was surprised by where I first made headway in my solve. I had great luck guessing the three long down entries that step diagonally at the center of the puzzle, in a spot that I often fill in last; conversely, it took me a while to complete the top right and bottom right corners of the grid.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael H. Keller
title: On These Apps, the Dark Promise of Mothers Sexually Abusing Children
description: Smartphone apps downloaded from Apple and Google can allow parents and other abusers to connect with pedophiles who pay to watch — and direct — criminal behavior.
content: The promotional photo showed a mother affectionately hugging and kissing her daughter. The girl, around 8 years old, smiled into the camera.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aimee Ortiz
title: Chi-Chi’s, the Former Mexican Restaurant Chain, Plans a Comeback
description: The chain, which closed in 2004, is poised for a revival next year after the son of one of the founders reached a deal with Hormel Foods.
content: Chi-Chi’s, the Mexican restaurant chain that closed 20 years ago, is poised for a revival next year after Michael McDermott, the son of one of the founders, announced a deal with Hormel Foods.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anant Agarwal
title: How A.I. Can Revive a Love of Learning
description: Modern technology offers new possibilities for transforming teaching.
content: This personal reflection is part of a series called Turning Points, in which writers explore what critical moments from this year might mean for the year ahead. You can read more by visiting the Turning Points series page.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By T.M. Brown
title: How Many Gift Guides Does a Person Need?
description: These days, everyone fancies themselves a curator of covetable items. Some find it exhausting.
content: Gwyneth Paltrow has one. So do Amanda Seyfried and the Kardashians. Magazines like New York, GQ and Vogue publish several. The boutique down the street just released one, as did seemingly every lifestyle writer on Substack — even the ones who said they really didn’t want to. The New York Times has a couple, too.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: How Catherine Russell, of ‘Perfect Crime,’ Spends Her Sundays
description: Ms. Russell, who hasn’t missed a performance of her Off Broadway show in nearly 30 years, fills her day with pets, church, teaching and two shows.
content: For most of the last four decades, Catherine Russell has maybe — possibly — murdered someone eight times a week.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Impeachment Bid Against South Korea’s President Fails
description: The country was thrown into deeper uncertainty after the governing party refused to oust President Yoon Suk Yeol. Protesters filled the streets of Seoul and vowed to keep the pressure on.
content: The country was thrown into deeper uncertainty after the governing party refused to oust President Yoon Suk Yeol. Protesters filled the streets of Seoul and vowed to keep the pressure on.

author: By Axel Boada
title: Notre-Dame Cathedral in Paris Reopens After Five-Year Renovation
description: World leaders and global dignitaries celebrated the cathedral’s reconstruction following a fire that devoured its roof in 2019.
content: World leaders and global dignitaries celebrated the cathedral’s reconstruction following a fire that devoured its roof in 2019.
